head.title: The Green, Not Mean, Of Bed-Stuy

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New York

hedline.hl1: The Green, Not Mean, Of Bed-Stuy

abstract.p: Orville Edwards, native of Jamaica who lives in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, takes group on nature tour of Bedford-Stuyvesant; organizers of tour say it is unusual in that it brings people--many of whom have never been to neighborhood they associate with urban blight--face to face with a place where nature merges with urban landscape; photo (M)

block.p: It is not easy being a tree in New York City, the tour guide ventured to guess yesterday as he walked a group of nearly a dozen guests through Fulton Park in Bedford-Stuyvesant.

It is not easy being a tree in New York City, the tour guide ventured to guess yesterday as he walked a group of nearly a dozen guests through Fulton Park in Bedford-Stuyvesant.
The guide, Orville Edwards, 26, said the biggest threats to trees in New York were pollution and cars knocking them over.

''This is the most commonly planted tree in the city,'' Mr. Edwards said, pointing to the thick trunk of a cross between an American sycamore and an Oriental sycamore in Fulton Park. ''They are very resistant to most disease and pollution.''

When most outsiders think of Bedford-Stuyvesant, Mr. Edwards said, images of fires, crime scenes and dilapidated buildings -- a so-called asphalt jungle -- fill their heads, based on what they have seen on television.

But yesterday, Mr. Edwards, a native of Jamaica who lives in Bedford-Stuyvesant, took a group on a nature tour there. The tour is one of dozens offered each summer by the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment, based in Park Slope.

The tour of Bedford-Stuyvesant is unusual, its organizers said, in that it brings people -- many of whom have never been to the neighborhood they associate with urban blight -- face to face with a place where nature merges with the urban landscape.
''We pretty much have more brownstones than anywhere in New York City,'' Mr. Edwards told the group, pointing out magnolias and gardens along tree-lined Stuyvesant Avenue in the historic district.
He talked not only about the squirrels and yellow-bellied sapsucker woodpeckers that frequent backyards, but also about where the limestone and brownstone on the buildings came from.
''You don't see much limestone in the neighborhood,'' said Mr. Edwards, an environmental coordinator with the Magnolia Tree Environmental Center. ''The brownstone is the most popular facade.''
Then he discussed the neighborhood's history: the Woolworth family once had a mansion there; many wealthy white residents moved out as blacks moved in from the Lower East Side in the 1950's.

As the tour group members strolled down Bedford-Stuyvesant's avenues and side streets, they at times seemed out of place. Most residents and business owners waved, while others gave only curious stares. Rodrique Morara, 59, a retired truck driver who lives across from the Boys and Girls School, where the group stopped to look at an American birch tree, gently needled them.
''That's poison ivy, of course, that is elementary,'' he said.
Stella Jouranis, 64, a retired secretary from Bay Ridge, said she had never been to Bedford-Stuyvesant and was surprised by its charm.
''I have lived in Brooklyn all my life and traveled around,'' she said. ''The streets are not this clean in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.''

She added that it was surprising that ''the neighborhood is so beautiful and it has a lot to offer, and how clean they keep the streets, and how kind all the people are.'' After a moment of reflection, Ms. Jouranis asked a reporter, ''Do you know how much buildings are going for in this neighborhood?''
